com.ti.debug.engine.scripting

Class Target

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ti.debug.engine.scripting.Target

  • public class Target
extends java.lang.Object
    This class encapsulates the target run-control methods (run, halt, reset, etc.) and serves as a container for the stepping classes. An instance of this class is automatically created when a new session is opened.

    // Create Environment and open a debug session
    ScriptingEnvironment env = new ScriptingEnvironment();
    DebugServer myServer = (DebugServer) env.getServer("DebugServer.1");
    DebugSession mySession = myServer.openSession("*", "*");

    ...

    // Reset the target then run
    mySession.target.reset();
    mySession.target.run();

    • Method Detail

      • connect

        public void connect()
             throws ScriptingException
        Connect/reconnect the debugger to the target. When working with hardware, the debugger will start-up with the target in a disconnected state. You must call connect() prior to performing any target operations. To facilitate running script on both hardware and simulators, calls to connect() and disconnect() are ignored if the target does not support connect/disconnect.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • connect

        public void connect(boolean waitUntilFullyConnected)
             throws ScriptingException
        This is the same as connect() except that if false is passed in, and the target is not in an accessible state after connecting, it will return and won't wait for the state to become valid. This means startup GEL scripts won't have run, memory/register/breakpoint accesses may not be possible, and the target may not be halted or even powered. If true is passed in, then the function will return only once it's in a valid state and all startup scripts have run. connect() is the same as calling this function with true passed in
        Parameters:
        waitUntilFullyConnected - false if it should return regardless of the target state
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • disconnect

        public void disconnect()
                throws ScriptingException
        Disconnect the debugger from the target. Use this method to disconnect the target from the debugger before temporarily disconnecting the emulator JTAG connection or performing a hardware reset of the target board. To facilitate running script on both hardware and simulators, calls to connect() and disconnect() are ignored if the target does not support connect/disconnect.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • getNumResetTypes

        public int getNumResetTypes()
        Returns the number of reset types the target supports
        Returns:
        int number of reset types supported.

      • getResetType

        public ResetType getResetType(int resetIndex)
                       throws ScriptingException
        Retrieve a ResetType object, which allows you to get information on the reset type, and issue the reset
        Parameters:
        resetIndex - (int) a number between 0 and getNumResetTypes()-1, associated with a ResetType supported by the target
        Returns:
        ResetType object associated with the given resetIndex.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • halt

        public void halt()
          throws ScriptingException
        Halt the target. Used to halt an asynchronous run initiated using Target.runAsynch().
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected()
                    throws ScriptingException
        Query the debugger to determine if the current target is connected or disconnected.
        Returns:
        true if the current target is connected (or if the target does not support connect/disconnect). false if the current target is disconnected.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected(boolean waitUntilFullyConnected)
                    throws ScriptingException
        This is the same as isConnected() except that if false is passed in, and the target is not in an accessible state after connecting, it will return true. If true is passed in, then it will only return true once the target is fully accessible and startup scripts have been run.
        Parameters:
        waitUntilFullyConnected - false if it should return true if connected, but not yet accessible and initialized
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • isHalted

        public boolean isHalted()
                 throws ScriptingException
        Query the debugger to determine if the current target is halted.
        Returns:
        true if the current target is halted, false if it is not.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws ScriptingException
        Reset the target.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • restart

        public void restart()
             throws ScriptingException
        Restart the target
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • run

        public void run()
         throws ScriptingException
        Issue a run command to the target but don't return control to the host application/script until the target has been halted due to to hitting a breakpoint, hitting the end of a program or timing out.

        If the scripting environment timeout is set to infinite and the target application has a continuous loop this method may never return.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • runAsynch

        public void runAsynch()
               throws ScriptingException
        Issue a run command to the target and return control immediately (even if target is still running) to the host application/script. Use Target.halt() to stop the target.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • waitForHalt

        public void waitForHalt()
                 throws ScriptingException
        Wait until the target has been halted due to to hitting a breakpoint, hitting the end of a program, or timing out.

        If the scripting environment timeout is set to infinite and the target application has a continuous loop this method may never return.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException
